urn:contentItem:5J21-VPD1-JBHT-D369-00000-00Four Days Remain Until New Hampshire Primary; Refugee Crisis in Germany; Twitter Suspends 100,ooo Accounts Possibly ISIS-Related; Michigan2016-02-05T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:51:46ZLexisNexisFour Days Remain Until New Hampshire Primary; Refugee Crisis in Germany; Twitter Suspends 100,ooo Accounts Possibly ISIS-Related; MichiganLanhamFULL TEXT

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

CHRIS CHRISTIE, (R) U.S. PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE: Marco Rubio is a guy who just has never had to make an difficult choice in his life. We elected a first time United States senator the last time and it didn't work out for him what work for us.

TED CRUZ, (R) U.S. PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE: If momentum are measured by the media, Marco Rubio would already be the republican nominee. And the media is telling bronze is the new gold.

MARCO RUBIO, (R) U.S. PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE: When people are talking a tough time in the campaign especially near the end, you see some desperation set in and start things a bit. I'm not too worried.

JEB BUSH, (R) U.S. PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE: The three leading contenders on the republican side. Think about their proven record of experience. Donald Trump. I will leave it at that.

DONALD TRUMP, (R) U.S. PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE: These people, I would like to use really foul language. I won't do it. I was going to say there are fully (muted) but I won't say that. No, it's true.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

DEIRDRE BOLTON, RISK & REWARD SHOW HOST: The gloves are off with four days to go to the New Hampshire primary.

This is Risk & Reward. I'm Deirdre Bolton.

There could be some surprises in New Hampshire. Pollsters have failed to predict Senator Cruz's first-place finish in Iowa.

So, as of today, in the Granite States, there is a new poll that shows Donald Trump holding the lead and Senator Rubio gaining ground as well.

My political power panel is here. Conservative commentator, Tammy Bruce, democratic strategist, John Rowley. Welcome to you both. What happens next? I'm going to ask you both the same question. What is your prediction, John, for New Hampshire? Who finishes in what order?

JOHN ROWLEY, DEMOCRATIC STRATEGIST: It's the last stand of the republican establishment. Bush, Kasich, Carly, Christie, all are pretty much are going to be done at the end. And I think if Rubio can continue this trend, I don't know that he's going to win, but he will have amazing momentum coming out of New Hampshire.

And I think one thing to keep in mind about polls especially around presidential primaries is, think about the impact they have on the campaigns and on voters when the last polls come out. Because, you know, voters react, campaigns reacted to do things.

So, one of the reasons that you had some surprising results in Iowa is campaigns did things differently. Sometimes out of desperation after there is a poll and voters react to that as well.

BOLTON: Tammy, if I have to ask you for gold, silver, and bronze, who do you think?

TAMMY BRUCE, CONSERVATIVE COMMENTATOR: Well, look, this is more difficult than Iowa. I correctly predicted Iowa for Ted Cruz, but here the independents play such a big role. I think Donald Trump has an excellent chance of winning but we see the same trajectory as we did in Iowa.

His numbers are trending down. Rubio is still trending up. Cruz is a little bit static. It is the last stand. Jeb Bush has put virtually everything into New Hampshire. Chris Christie is surprisingly not doing well at all in the polls.

I think though, when you're dealing with number one, I predict Donald Trump is going to win this one. And the fight is going to be per second. Now Ted Cruz still has a ground game second to none. He's able to target those who are inclined already to support him. And by the way though, this could all be changed if Cruz and Trump don't stop fighting.

If they divide their own vote that is what will give Rubio a chance to move into second. So, if Cruz and Trump stop fighting, Cruz will take second. If they don't, Rubio will take second. That's exactly where Rubio wants to be leading into South Carolina.

BOLTON: OK. So, Tammy, I heard you loudly and clearly. You think that Donald Trump will win New Hampshire.

BRUCE: Yes.

BOLTON: I have to assume that's because there are so many independents...

BRUCE: Yes.

BOLTON: ... and he seems to be appealing in that way to people. Here he is when confronted at a town hall in New Hampshire.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Throughout the course of this campaign you said some disparaging comments about women, about people from other countries, other religions, and about everybody who has disagreed with you. Explain to me how I can look at my daughters and have them look up to a President Trump as a role model.

TRUMP: Nobody has more respect for women that I do. I have so many women executive. I have been great to women and women have been great to me. They've done a great job. I do bring up things that are things that people don't want to bring up. When I brought up the Muslim problem, you know, it's very interesting. I brought that problem up and all of a sudden the world started going wild and now the world is agreeing with me.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BOLTON: John, what do you think of Trump's response there?

ROWLEY: Well, I'm waiting for him to take credit for inventing the internet. I mean, he's really delusional that he is the first person that's talked about so many things in this campaign when a lot of different people in another Republican Party have talked about them for a long time.

Whether it's going to impact him or not, I mean, he's appealing to a sliver of the electorate, really the most conservative Tea Party angry or whiter or anti-Obama wing of the party sliver of the national electorate.

And I don't know that it will impact him in New Hampshire. I mean, the thing about New Hampshire voters though, is they are contrarians and I'm not sure if that means they deliver a surprise for Trump. They certainly have delivered surprises before, but, you know, that there may be one of those equal and opposite reactions to some late polling that we've certainly seen in both parties in New Hampshire in all of that.

BRUCE: Can I chime in one additional element that helps Trump...

BOLTON: Sure.

BRUCE: is the heroin addiction there in New Hampshire. It's a big issue. We know that it's related to the border, to the open border, to the ability of drugs moving up into this country. That is going to be something that matters from.

And also I notice that he did change his approach. He noted that he might - - he would like to win but he is not sure. I mean, his demeanor does seem to have shifted off of that for a span of 12 hours.

(CROSSTALK)

BOLTON: So, his tone is changing?

BRUCE: Yes, a little bit.

BOLTON: OK.

BRUCE: And I think that will -- that will help him obviously.

BOLTON: BOLTON: Tammy and John, stay with me, please. Other things to ask you about. In the meantime, on the other side of the aisle, last night's democratic debate Senator Sanders and Hillary Clinton sparred hard.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

BERNIE SANDERS, (D) U.S. PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE: Secretary Clinton does represent the establishment.

HILLARY CLINTON, (D) U.S. PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE: Senator Sanders is the only person who I think would characterize me a woman running to be the first woman president as exemplifying the establishment and enough is enough.

SANDERS: And one of the things we should do is not only talk the talk but walk the walk. I am very proud to be the only candidate up here who does not have a super PAC, who's not using huge sums of money from Wall Street.

(APPLAUSE)

CLINTON: You will not find that I ever changed the view or a vote because of any donation that I ever received. So, I think it's time to end the very artful smear that you and your campaign have been carrying out in recent weeks. And let's talk -- let's about the issues.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BOLTON: My political power panel will be back with me shortly to tell you what they think of those two sides.

All right. Fox Business is going to be bringing you live coverage of our nation's first primary. It happens Tuesday, February 9the. Neil Cavuto, he's going to be bringing you those results from New Hampshire as soon as they come in starting at 7.55 Eastern Time.

If you look at the markets today, stocks got crushed. Fewer than forecast jobs were added to the U.S. economy. In his State of the Union address, President Obama had this to say to critics.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

BARACK OBAMA, UNITED STATES OF AMERICA PRESIDENT: Anyone claiming that America's economy is in decline is peddling fiction.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BOLTON: Economist thought 190,000 jobs would be added to the U.S. economy. It was a lower number, 151,000, so 39,000 less. There is a new report that also shows the number of layoffs hit a six-month high soaring 218 percent from December to January.

Gary Smith is with me now. He is the president of Kadina Group. So, Gary, some economists are calling this jobs report mix. What is your take?

GARY B. SMITH, KADINA GROUP PRESIDENT: I think that's optimistic. I think it's terrible would be the better word. Look, there was, what, 151,000 jobs created. Two-thirds of those jobs, Deirdre, were in retail. One third was in food services.

So, you know the job creator was not the CEO of McDonald's. It's people behind the counter flipping burgers or it's the person working the menswear section at Wal-Mart.

Those are the kinds of jobs we're creating. So, we're creating terrible jobs not even enough of them and then the other important numbers as you well know is the labor force participation rate. That continues to be dismal -- it's lower than it was a year ago. Meaning the number of jobs we're creating is not keeping up even with the population growth.

BOLTON: Well, Gary, to your point, it's something like the lowest as we've talked since the late '70s or early '80s. I'm taking your point on that. Gary Smith, thanks for that short, sweet perspective on today's jobs report.

Well, from national concerns to local ones, two NYPD officers were shot at a Bronx public housing complex in New York City. The incident follows the shootings of six other on-duty officers in a little bit more than a year. Now, four of those officers died.

New York City real estate executive, Don Peebles is with me now. Don, it's great to see you.

DON PEEBLES, NYC REAL ESTATE CHIEF EXECUTVE: Good to see you.

BOLTON: Does this change your view at all about doing business in New York?

PEEBLES: Well, look.

(CROSSTALK)

BOLTON: But it seems to be increasing violence is what I mean.

PEEBLES: Well, I think what's happening here is the administration running the city is tone deaf and not living in reality. We are having a dramatic increase in random violence and that's frightening visitors from coming to New York and it's also making business owners more concerned.

And then you add that to these other discussions about raising tax and adding more regulations to the private sector and it forces people to look at alternative cities.

BOLTON: So, you've said in the past you are considering or would consider a run for mayor of New York City. Do incidences such of these propel you forward in your thinking to the extent of, OK, I could do better than what's happening now.

PEEBLES: Absolutely. That we have right now is we have criminals walking around with weapons and armed and...

(CROSSTALK)

BOLTON: And they are shooting police officers in uniforms.

PEEBLES: ... they are shooting police officers who are sitting docks. We have slashing of women. We have women being raped who are tourist. Rape in central park. And the mayor is going to Iowa to knock on doors for Hillary Clinton when the city is in chaos. And so, yes, a bit concern.

BOLTON: So, let me ask you, speaking of being tone deaf, I mean, we do want to play some clips from Mayor de Blasio. Here is one of them.

OK. Actually, we don't have that, but in essence he was essentially trying to speak in favor of the police force. But he has come under so much fire for not protecting the force.

PEEBLES: Well, what has happened is that the mayor set the tone very early. Bill de Blasio, after the grand jury decided not to indict the officers for Eric Gardner's death he empathized with people who were in fear of police violence as opposed to recognizing he is the leader of the police department.

But the reality is, he's tried to racially polarize this issue. And frankly, the minority community, African-American and Latinos disproportionately carry the burden of crimes and there are no more conservative New Yorker when it comes to law enforcement than African- Americans.

BOLTON: So, let me ask you before we go, there is a Black Lives Matter candidate, who actually, or I should activists, excuse me, who wants to put himself forward to be the mayor of Baltimore. Is it a good mix to have an activist turned mayor?

PEEBLES: No. We see it in New York right now. Bill de Blasio was a paid protester as a public advocate, so he was an activist. Being mayor of major city or any city for that matter you're performing administrative functions and municipal functions.

(CROSSTALK)

BOLTON: You have to serve everyone.

PEEBLES: And also you have to be a good manager. These are multibillion dollar organizations, activists belong in running for Congress, running for the United States Senate. They belong, maybe on the city council but they do not belong as managers.

Our city needs to be run by competent managers who have experienced in managing and leading businesses or large organizations.

BOLTON: All right. Don, well, when you're ready for your announcement you know where to come.

PEEBLES: Thank you.

BOLTON: Don Peebles joining me there, in the meantime, real estate exec.

The refugee crisis is worsening in Germany. Another sexual assault in Cologne. This one happened live as a reporter was working on air. My next guest says Germany refugee cartoon etiquette is not working.

On a separate note, notorious drug CEO, Martin Shkreli plead the fifth yesterday.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

ELIJAH CUMMINGS, MARYLAND STATE REPRESENTATIVE: You can look away if you would like, but I wish you could see the faces of people no matter what Ms. Redzclaff (ph) says who cannot get the drugs that they need.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BOLTON: This so-called pharma bro now has posted a new video to YouTube and you will not believe what he is saying.

And, Twitter announcing a moments ago, it is suspending more than 100,000 accounts it believes to be propaganda parts from ISIS. Is this better than Facebook like attack strategy? Captain Chuck Nash is with me up next.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SHERYL SANDBERG, FACEBOOK COO: They launched what they called a like attack on the Facebook page of the NPD.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BOLTON: Social media company Twitter just announcing it will shut down more than 100,000 accounts that are deemed to be part of ISIS recruiting accounts.

Retired navy captain and Fox News military analyst, Chuck Nash is with me now. Captain, what is your take on Twitter's decision?

CHUCK NASH, RETIRED U.S. NAVY: Well, I think there is to coming to public pressure because people are outraged that these bad guys are being allowed to use the same social networks that law-abiding people are and they're disgusted with it. And I think they're valuing to pressure to shut it down.

BOLTON: So, does this just mean though that terrorists will just find another method by which to communicate?

NASH: Oh, absolutely. They are not going to stop communicating. So, there may be a good news story in this for our intelligence community because they may be one step ahead of them finding out what their plan B was for communications, and maybe this is really going to put them communicating on networks that are a little more accessible to our NSA and other intelligence operations.

BOLTON: So, Captain, Facebook does not want to be left out of the conversation or seen as being negligent. Here is the COO, Sheryl Sandberg.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SANDBERG: So, that's the antidote to bad speech is good speech. They launched what they called a like attack on the Facebook page of the NPD. So, the NPD is the neo-Nazi party. That page is filled with intolerance. And rather than scream and protest they got 100,000 people to like the page who did not like the page and then put messages of tolerance on the page.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BOLTON: Chuck, what do you make of this kind of vigilante social media participation? Is that the right way to go?

NASH: No, that's just silly. That's just people trying to feel good about something and doing nothing more than making a couple of keystrokes on a handheld device. That's silly. That's like, release our girls or whatever that was in Nigeria.

(CROSSTALK)

BOLTON: In Nigeria, yes.

NASH: Yes. When Boko Haram took the 300 girls. That means absolutely nothing. Its people trying to save their consciences, it's nothing.

BOLTON: All right. Going from nothing to something deserving and significant. A female journalists reporting on the carnival in Cologne, Germany, says she was sexually assaulted on live TV.

NASH: Right.

BOLTON: So, we're showing a video right now. There is a man making gestures behind her.

NASH: Right.

BOLTON: The reporter also saying someone grabbed her. How is Germany going to address this issue and what does the U.S. have to learn from Germany's example?

NASH: Well, Deirdre, that's a -- that's a really long answer questions but I'll keep it short. What you are actually seeing here is what happen in Sweden in a microcosm. In the 1970's, rape was almost unknown in Sweden.

The government did a study several years later in the '80s and found out the migrants from North Africa, the Muslim males that were coming up were 23 times more likely to commit rape. So, now you're seeing all of Europe.

In Germany, last year they had 100,000 applicants for asylum. Last month, 100,000 asylum seekers showed up just last month, and they're saying they're going to take 800,000. These societies have got to get over this political correctness because they are naivet, is jeopardizing public safety and the safety of their entire culture.

BOLTON: And we have heard Angela Merkel, of course, the German Chancellor saying, listen, this is temporary. Asylum here in Germany is temporary and they are going to endeavor to send a lot of the refugees back, which I think unfortunately, for Germany's going to be very complicated.

What do you think though, of Cologne establishing this kind of safe zone for women, in other words, almost segregating out its own women for their won protection which...

NASH: Exactly. So, here's the deal. This thing is like Mardi Gras in New Orleans. So, it is -- yes, there is a lot of booze flying around. People are drunk, they're happy and everything. But these gangs are moving around. So, what are these women supposed to do?

Go into this tent area? That sounds like a lot of fun. So, really what the German police are saying there are 2500 cops in this deal and there are about 1.5 million visitors in Cologne in this Mardi Gras-type events.

So, who do they penalize? Whose freedom do they restrict? The women's. That's nuts. They're not going to do that.

BOLTON: It's nuts. All right. Captain Chuck Nash, we thank you as always. Glad to have you here.

NASH: My pleasure, Deirdre.

BOLTON: From overseas to Michigan, the Flint water crisis just getting worse and worse. New e-mail showing officials knew that the water was poisoned.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: I'm outrage that the EPA continues to allow this type of dishonesty.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: For that much money we poisoned the kids in Flint. Didn't we?

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: I find it despicable.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BOLTON: Our legal expert is going to tell us who he thinks is going to jail over it.

Also, pharma bro, all he did was smirk yesterday.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

CUMMINGS: You can look away if you like but I wish you could see the faces of people no matter what Ms. Redzclaff (ph) says who cannot get the drugs that they need.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BOLTON: Well, he is speaking out. Martin Shkreli has a new YouTube post. We'll play it for you after this.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

MARTIN SHKRELI, FORMER TURING PHARMACEUTICALS CEO: Invoke my Fifth Amendment privilege. I invoke my Fifth Amendment privilege. I invoke my Fifth Amendment privilege.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

GLENN GROTHMAN, WISCONSIN STATE CONGRESSMAN: The question there was a cover up, and the cover up of the worst kind. You've been costing people money and people ask money as well. You are costing people their health and maybe their lives.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BOLTON: That was Wisconsin Congressman Glenn Grothman on the unfolding water crisis in Flint, Michigan. Now there are new e-mails released by the Liberal Group Progress Michigan alleging that principle adviser to Michigan Governor Rick Snyder was made aware of the crisis 10 months prior to the governor informing the public.

Tammy Bruce is back with me now. So, Tammy, who was going to be held accountable for 100,000 children being poisoned?

BRUCE: Well, if we leave it up to the establishment, no one. We haven't seen anyone when it comes to federal scandals that are being taken to task for what they have done. I'd call a while ago for Governor Snyder's resignation.

Look, Flint was under a state appointed emergency manager when this occurred and the decision to switch to the Flint River was made. Ultimately, any leader knows that the box stops with them.

Now with these e-mails showing that his main aide knew about this 10 months before he said he did and this continues to go on is outrageous. Now, look, I'm a conservative. I'm not a republican but I think that there's got to be responsibility for everyone across the board.

Look, it's a progressive group that found this out. I don't care who founded out. But the truth is the truth. Facts matter and I think Snyder should take a step and resign at this point because if -- and look, the EPA -- the scandal of government -- everybody. Everybody.

(CROSSTALK)

BOLTON: Yes. It's a scandal. I mean, there's no other way to say it. It's a scandal.

BRUCE: Yes.

BOLTON: Speaking of health matters from a different lens, pharma bro, Martin's Shkreli just releasing a video blasting Congress on YouTube. Here it is.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SHKRELI: The reality is it's pathetic that they needed me to get publicity for themselves. And, you know, I think it's transparent. I think it's pathetic. They could have had a closed chamber meeting with me. They didn't want that. They could have given me immunity, they didn't want that. The last thing in the world they would want me to do is to testify because it would be very embarrassing to them.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BOLTON: Shkreli blasting Congress after getting an earful from lawmakers.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

CUMMINGS: You can look away if you would like but I wish you could see the faces of people, no matter what Ms. Redzclaff (ph) says who cannot get the drugs that they need.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BOLTON: Tammy, to your credit you got into it Twitter altercation with Shkreli. He does still have problems. He can go in front of that House hearing and take the Fifth, but he also has security fraud charges against him, right?

BRUCE: Well, look, he's facing some serious criminal charges. I'm shocked that his lawyers are allowing him to post things up on the internet at this point. You know, what I think what happened in Congress was appropriate.

A lot of Americans don't realize what this guy did. But more than that it really isn't all about him despite his feelings that it is, it's his own narcissism obviously. This is about the nature of the kinds of choices being made in the pharmaceutical industry, but also the kind of person that we're dealing with.

And so, I think Congress did, I think everyone a favor, in highlighting this guy's behavior and his attitude because when you -- look, I'm all for profit. I like the pharmaceutical industries saves people's lives, but this is the kind of things that we've to make sure that we focus on.

For Shkreli himself I'm surprised that no one in his family has intervened. He's obviously a young man with some problems facing very serious charges. And his lawyers stopped him at one point in the congressional hearing from speaking which would -- which would have ended his Fifth Amendment right to not speak and they should also try to protect him from himself at this point.

BOLTON: I was going to say he is lucky that his lawyer is on the case because his lawyer is also trying to explain away with seems to be, from an objective view, very bad behavior.

Tammy Bruce, thank you so much.

BRUCE: Sure.

BOLTON: See you in a bit.

In the meantime, moving to the big game on Sunday, Super Bowl brings in big bucks for the players on the field whether they win or lose. Athletes earning more than a million dollars are subject to a so-called jock tax.

Carolina Panthers quarterback, Cam Newton may be feeling it extra hard.

Cheryl Casone is with me now live from San Francisco. Cheryl, I know you are ready for the big game but it is significant for all of these athletes that is being played in California, right?

CHERYL CASONE, FOX BUSINESS CORRESPONDENT: Well, absolutely. Because of the tax situation that the tax raised that are paid in the State of California. And there are some of the highest of the world frankly. But, you know, it was interesting, two years ago, Peyton Manning paid a lot of taxes in the State of New Jersey because they won.

We thought those numbers were big. Cam Newton, if he wins on Sunday, he's going to be paying so much bigger numbers.

First, we'll take a look at state tax rate for the State of California. Again, it's called the jock tax. That's what we've named it here, 13.3 percent. That is the amount paid on earnings per athletes who earned a million dollars or more and of course most of them do earn more than million dollars or more.

But let's look at the income that you would get from the Super Bowl. No matter who you are. The losing team for each player, $102,000, right? For the winning team, 51,000. That's the income. Remember, California gets a tax on every single penny that you make in their state.

Now, Cam Newton and the Panthers. OK. Now if they win, Cam Newton, in particular, if he pays the State of California, his tax bill for 2016, he's been, what do you say, guys, $159,560. That if he wins.

If he loses about the same story. Why -- why bother playing at Panthers if loss in the Super Bowl. Mr. Newton will pay $159,200 in tax, Deirdre, for 2016.

He's also saying because it's a duty tax basically. Duty days in a calendar year is how the State of California equates this. Your annual income, your calendar income versus the amount of days that you work and the more you make the worse the tax is.

But I got to say if would be nice to see Cam Newton win on Sunday. Back to you in New York.

(CROSSTALK)

DEIRDRE BOLTON, RISK & REWARD SHOW HOST: I was just going to say. It's a good weather in California, higher taxes. I don't know if the players are comfortable with that trade. In the meantime, Cheryl Casone, thank you so much. Live, you can see her there at the Super Bowl.

All right. Hillary Clinton says she is not an establishment candidate.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

HILLARY CLINTON, (D) U.S. PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE: Senator sanders is the only person who, I think would characterize me as a woman running to be the first woman president as exemplifying the establishment, and enough is enough.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BOLTON: Our next guest says that Hillary Clinton keeps misplaying the woman card. We'll talk about that.

Also, there is fatal frame collapse here in New York City, one person killed, three injured, a 500-foot crane came falling down during rush hour. The lone fatality was a man sitting in a parked car, a worker at a nearby building caught the whole thing on his cell phone.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Almost even with us. There he goes. He's moving fast now. He's dropping it really quick. (muted) That thing looks like it's going to fall. Holy. It's falling. It's falling. Falling. Oh, it broke. Holy!

(END VIDEO CLIP)

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

BERNIE SANDERS, (D) U.S. PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE: One of the things we should do is not only talk the talk but walk the walk. I am very proud to be the only candidate up here who does not have a super PAC who's not raising huge sums of money from Wall Street.

CLINTON: You will not find that I ever changed a view or a vote because of any donations that I ever received. So, I think it's time to end the very artful smear that you and your campaign have been carrying out in recent weeks. And let's talk -- let's talk about the issues.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BOLTON: Tensions were high as Hillary Clinton and Senator Sanders sparred hard over issues such as campaign finance. Also terms such as, establishment candidate and progressive candidate.

My political power panel is back. Tammy Bruce, John Rowley. So, Tammy, what do you make of Hillary's connections, fundraising from Wall Street? Is this going to cause her a problem? Or does it pale in comparison to the e-mail scandal?

TAMMY BRUCE, CONSERVATIVE COMMENTATOR: Look, I think it's all a problem. It's all linked. It's all about integrity. Obviously the American people don't trust her for a reason. She has been the first lady, she's been a senator from New York, the Secretary of State, and she stands there and says she's not the establishment?

One good thing -- I'm a feminist, I was the president of the national organization for women in L.A. and was on their board. We do know women now have moved into the power rankings, we can be establishment, and I want a woman to be president, but just not that one.

And I think she has to realize that she's not the only flame holder that we know what she's doing. Women have other choices now. And I think that whether it's the e-mails or even who she is, her own positioning, the money she takes, all of it speaks to a lack of trust, a lack of credibility, and a woman who tends to make things up as she goes along.

BOLTON: All right. So, John, you heard Tammy's points there, I just want to bring in Hillary Clinton's comments on saying that she is not an establishment candidate.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

CLINTON: Senator Sanders is the only person who I think would characterize me, a woman running to be the first woman president as exemplifying the establishment. And enough is enough.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BOLTON: So, John, that's obviously Hillary's take there. But about the e- mails, how much credibility -- how much is this going to cost her? There are months to go until November. We don't know what else is going to come out.

JOHN ROWLEY, DEMOCRATIC STRATEGIST: Well, Senator Sanders has kind of made the e-mail issue a moot point in the primary. And the establishment argument is a little bit off base. I mean, I haven't seen many candidates lose in the -- unlike the republican primary what's going on where there is a battle over who's too moderate and establishment.

And frankly, Hillary Clinton has her toe in a lot of different parts of the Democratic Party overtime. And frankly, I mean, the challenge she's had and almost the single issue that Bernie Sanders has made is the Wall Street angle.

And so, it's -- I think it's less of an establishment issue as kind of the Wall Street message, which has given her some problems. And -- so anyway, I think it's more Wall Street than an establishment issue.

BOLTON: All right. Now, Hillary does sound pretty confident, though, as far as the e-mails go. But I hear what you're saying, Tammy, this is all wrapped up in the issue of credibility.

BRUCE: Well, it is. And look, she's a robot. I mean, she's trained to sound like she's confident. She makes things up. Look, Bernie -- Bernie Sanders got more aggressive with her after that meeting with Barack Obama in the White House.

And I think that you've realized -- there's one -- one female senator that has not endorsed Hillary Clinton and that's Elizabeth Warren. Barack Obama is not moving either. You've got this investigation with the FBI.

But what we're dealing with Hillary here is whether it's establishment or Wall Street or you might think the two are the same, I happen to love Wall Street, is the fact that her daughter who is campaigning for her, lives in a $10 million condo in New York, a young woman who's married to a hedge fund manager.

I mean, the attempts to portray herself as an outsider is in and of itself insulting. Bernie Sanders made $5 million more last month than Hillary did. This message is resonating because democrats are also sick and tired of what's been going on.

ROWLEY: Well, that's a pretty good litany of things that republican primary voters are concerned about. But once we pivot to the general election, a lot of these problems are just going to seem petty and political and partisan.

And in terms of the e-mail, I mean, there's no precedent in the history of the United States where a credible presidential candidate has been indicted in a campaign and...

(CROSSTALK)

BOLTON: Yes.

ROWLEY: ... there needs to something dark and documented and provable...

BOLTON: Well, time to go.

BRUCE: She won't be the -- she won't be the nominee. So, it won't be an issue.

BOLTON: John and Tammy, thank you both.

ROWLEY: Dream on.

BOLTON: Glad to have you here.

ROWLEY: Right.

BOLTON: We just want to highlight quickly what happened in the markets. Stocks got crushed. There was a monthly job number missed.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

BARACK OBAMA, UNITED STATES OF AMERICA PRESIDENT: Anyone claiming that America's economy is in decline is pedaling fiction.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BOLTON: New reports says investors are ditching stocks putting a lot in cash. Find out if you should be doing the same.

Also, a $500 million price tag for a premium 30-second Super Bowl commercial. Small businesses are usually left in the dark but not this one. Bill Rancic, "Apprentice" winner is going to tell us about how he's giving away a free Super Bowl ad to one lucky business. We'll tell you which one it is, next.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: The day of reckoning is upon us. My brother, what is life if not to die a glorious death. But tonight we are in the heart of. Rome awaitens and welcome them.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BOLTON: That is a Super Bowl ad, set to air this Sunday, the small business small business Death Wish Coffee, it's scored big with into a quick book small business competition.

Former apprentice winner, small business advocate, Bill Rancic has teamed up with into it. Bill, glad to have you here. So, this 30-second spot on Sunday cost an average $5 million. Why did this company, this crazy coffee company win?

BILL RANCIC, FORMER "APPRENTICE" WINNER: Well, you know, we -- we spent the last year traveling around the country looking for small businesses to participate in this competition called small business big game. And we had tens of thousands of small businesses apply. Got narrowed down, narrowed down, eventually everyone in America got to vote. And they chose Death Wish Coffee.

It was just a great story. The young man started this business literally moving home with his mom at the age of 30 and put his lifesavings on the line and started it. He had an idea, he had a dream, and I think people really connected with that story because that's how 98 percent of the small businesses that are out there today started. So, it's a really connection.

(CROSSTALK)

BOLTON: Yes. Facebook started in a dorm room.

RANCIC: And it's just one way of celebrating small business.

BOLTON: Indeed. To your point, Bill, Facebook starting in a dorm room, Google starting in a very modest split level house. The founder of Death Wish Coffee, Mike Brown, was just moments ago on after the bell, we're going to play a clip for anyone who missed that.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SANDRA SMITH, FOX BUSINESS ANCHOR: I mean, what is it -- what do you think it's going to be like to sit there during the Super Bowl and know that millions of people are watching your ad?

MIKE BROWN, DEATH WISH COFFEE OWNER: Yes. Millions are people are going to discover Death Wish Coffee for the first time. And I mean, for a small business owner, it's a dream come true.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BOLTON: All right. So, there is his comment there. Now you, Bill, are the original winner of the first "Apprentice" show. So, we have to ask. Have you talked to Trump?

RANCIC: You know, I haven't spoken to him in several months. But certainly following his campaign closely and watching his rise to success in the campaign.

BOLTON: What do you think given your experience with him?

RANCIC: Well, I can tell you this. He knows how to hire good people.

BOLTON: All right.

RANCIC: He hired me 13 years ago.

BOLTON: There you go. Proof.

RANCIC: But, you know, he's someone who has a proven track record, and he knows how to get deals done.

BOLTON: Bill Rancic, we thank you. Looking forward to seeing the ad live on Sunday. Bill Rancic joining us there.

Stocks got crushed today. The NASDAQ down more than 3 percent. Even the tech darlings from last year sold off in today's session.

Gary Smith back with me now. So, Gary, investors are pouring more than $200 billion into cash. Is this the right move?

GARY B. SMITH, KADINA GROUP PRESIDENT: Well, it's the expected move. I mean, most retail investors base their investing on emotions or the momentum of the market. And since July, which, you know, we've seen the great excess out, we've had the big market dip in August of last year. We had the big market dip of January. Some would say it's still continuing.

Who could blame them out there? You can't get any returns on bonds so where are you going to go cash? Now, to the quick answer to your question, is that the way to go? Maybe back in July it was. Now I would say I think we have further to go down.

So, if you have, say, $20,000 to invest, I would put 10,000 in the market right now and wait for further pull back.

BOLTON: All right. Gary, thank you very much. We love specific advice. Gary Smith joining us there of Kadina Group.

Well, a huge stock drop. Speaking of networking site LinkedIn down more than 40 percent. With me next a Silicon Valley investor on whether or not another tech crash is coming.

Fifteen percent work force layoff, Yahoo CEO Marissa Mayer receiving criticism over -- well, a lot of the moves that she's making. We'll fill you in.

Plus, a fatal crane collapse right here in New York City. One person killed, three others injured, a 500-foot crane came curling down during rush hour. The lone fatality was a man sitting in a parked car. A worker at a nearby building caught the whole thing on his cell phone.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Almost even with us. There he goes. He's moving fast now. He's dropping it really quick. (muted) That thing looks like it's going to fall. Holy. It's falling. It's falling. Falling. Oh, it broke. Holy!

(END VIDEO CLIP)

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BOLTON: Tech stocks sold off today. Especially ones that had more than 50 percent gains last year. So, Facebook, Amazon, Netflix, all down more than 5 percent in today's session. SoftTech Venture Capital founder managing partner, Jeff Clavier is with me now. Jeff, it's great to see you.

JEFF CLAVIER, SOFTTECH VENTURE CAPITAL FOUNDER: It's good to be back.

BOLTON: When you see the NASDAQ down more than 3 percent, when you looked at LinkedIn which was a big tech darling for many years, down something like 45 percent. What do you think of the tech environment right now?

CLAVIER: So, there's been a lot of nervousness in the market. We know that since the beginning of the year. And there's been sort of expectations that were priced in terms of continued growth. And they didn't deliver based on how they said 2016 would shape up for them. And so, you know.

BOLTON: So, Jeff, you've invest at the very beginning.

CLAVIER: Very.

BOLTON: And then you help a little bit as the company grows. Does this change when you see big drops like this? Does this change the way that you're investing now?

CLAVIER: No. Not at the worst stage. We still do roughly 15 investments per year and will continue doing so in 2016. I think the way the impact we'll see is how downstream investors investing behind us will see growth rounds will just change in terms of valuations and that two market realities.

Because there's no way you can have a disconnect between public market comes which have clearly falling down a lot this year and what was paid for unicorns in the current market.

BOLTON: You have invested in some -- well, numerous hot stocks. Some of which are still private, some of which are still public, which public one are the most proud of? That you saw early, you got in early.

CLAVIER: I'm still happy what Fitbit has done. Obviously, down 50 percent this year, but I think that it's actually the company which makes the world a better place because it helps people to get in shape.

And I think that hopefully the market we understand that, you know, the Apple watch won't kill it, that all of its competitors won't kill them (Inaudible) and the new line up of products that are actually pretty exciting. The market doesn't like it. But, you know, still has 17 awards.

BOLTON: There's a new design, it looks good.

CLAVIER: Fashion focused.

BOLTON: With a company, though, such as Yahoo clearly on the ropes. Do you get anxious that there are fewer potential buyers for any other companies that you might be investing?

CLAVIER: So, you know, it's actually pretty unusual to see those valuations that are coming down which actually are going to get the buyers back to the table of negotiating with hot company's potential buyouts.

Because over the last couple of years the expectations were so high that the remaining (ph) market was pretty tipped. With, you know, all those valuations sort of coming down. I've heard numerous sort of called, there are people saying, OK, well, none of the market is back on track, let's have a discussion.

BOLTON: All right. That's the good start of all things. Jeff Clavier, thank you so much. Joining me there, partner at SoftTech VC.

Super Bowl Sunday is this weekend. You know that. Cheryl Casone is there. An update from her in just a minute.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BOLTON: It's Super Bowl weekend. Broncos quarterback, Peyton Manning trying snag one more championship as retirement looms. The rising Carolina Panthers star, Cam Newton trying to lead his team to the first Super Bowl title.

Cheryl Casone is there in San Francisco. What's the atmosphere like, Cheryl?

CASONE: Well, this is the NFL experience. It's a fan's dream. If you love football, in fact, we're right in front of radio row, we've been here a lot of the afternoon. And this is where a lot of the big players.

I mean, you should have seen Tony Romo, quarterback for the Cowboys. You couldn't even move in this space. So, it's a lot of fans, a lot of media, a lot of companies. Everybody trying to kind of get a piece of the football pie, if you will.

All the buzz, I got to say, is about Peyton Manning. So many questions about whether or not he's going to retire after the season and still no answers from him. He's going to have sell everybody himself.

Roger Goodell was here, of course, a lot of the executives. Also, about a million people coming into the San Francisco Bay area. Security has been insane. Blackhawk helicopters actually flying above the skies at San Francisco.

The FBI, Department of Homeland Security surveilling everything. There's camera everywhere. And I got to tell you, anybody that is going to be at the Levi Stadium on Sunday, for the big game, Deirdre, smile for the surveillance camera because they've got so many cameras on that stadium. They are concerned about security.

They wanted to make sure that Super Bowl 50 goes off without a hitch. I got to tell you, the other big piece of buzz right now and you're going to love this, Coldplay, Beyonc,, Bruno Mars, right? There is a mystery guest cannot get it out of the half time, people. We've all been trying today, but with all those reporters and we don't know.

BOLTON: Well, enjoy it all. Cheryl Casone joining us there from the Super Bowl site. Speaking of super stars, Making Money with Charles Payne starts now.

END

urn:contentItem:5W2T-9RC1-DY0W-40S0-00000-00Four Days Remain Until New Hampshire Primary; Refugee Crisis in Germany; Twitter Suspends 100,ooo Accounts Possibly ISIS-Related; Michigan2016-02-05T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:51:46ZLexisNexisFour Days Remain Until New Hampshire Primary; Refugee Crisis in Germany; Twitter Suspends 100,ooo Accounts Possibly ISIS-Related; MichiganLanhamFULL TEXT

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

CHRIS CHRISTIE, (R) U.S. PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE: Marco Rubio is a guy who just has never had to make an difficult choice in his life. We elected a first time United States senator the last time and it didn't work out for him what work for us.

TED CRUZ, (R) U.S. PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE: If momentum are measured by the media, Marco Rubio would already be the republican nominee. And the media is telling bronze is the new gold.

MARCO RUBIO, (R) U.S. PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE: When people are talking a tough time in the campaign especially near the end, you see some desperation set in and start things a bit. I'm not too worried.

JEB BUSH, (R) U.S. PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE: The three leading contenders on the republican side. Think about their proven record of experience. Donald Trump. I will leave it at that.

DONALD TRUMP, (R) U.S. PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE: These people, I would like to use really foul language. I won't do it. I was going to say there are fully (muted) but I won't say that. No, it's true.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

DEIRDRE BOLTON, RISK & REWARD SHOW HOST: The gloves are off with four days to go to the New Hampshire primary.

This is Risk & Reward. I'm Deirdre Bolton.

There could be some surprises in New Hampshire. Pollsters have failed to predict Senator Cruz's first-place finish in Iowa.

So, as of today, in the Granite States, there is a new poll that shows Donald Trump holding the lead and Senator Rubio gaining ground as well.

My political power panel is here. Conservative commentator, Tammy Bruce, democratic strategist, John Rowley. Welcome to you both. What happens next? I'm going to ask you both the same question. What is your prediction, John, for New Hampshire? Who finishes in what order?

JOHN ROWLEY, DEMOCRATIC STRATEGIST: It's the last stand of the republican establishment. Bush, Kasich, Carly, Christie, all are pretty much are going to be done at the end. And I think if Rubio can continue this trend, I don't know that he's going to win, but he will have amazing momentum coming out of New Hampshire.

And I think one thing to keep in mind about polls especially around presidential primaries is, think about the impact they have on the campaigns and on voters when the last polls come out. Because, you know, voters react, campaigns reacted to do things.

So, one of the reasons that you had some surprising results in Iowa is campaigns did things differently. Sometimes out of desperation after there is a poll and voters react to that as well.

BOLTON: Tammy, if I have to ask you for gold, silver, and bronze, who do you think?

TAMMY BRUCE, CONSERVATIVE COMMENTATOR: Well, look, this is more difficult than Iowa. I correctly predicted Iowa for Ted Cruz, but here the independents play such a big role. I think Donald Trump has an excellent chance of winning but we see the same trajectory as we did in Iowa.

His numbers are trending down. Rubio is still trending up. Cruz is a little bit static. It is the last stand. Jeb Bush has put virtually everything into New Hampshire. Chris Christie is surprisingly not doing well at all in the polls.

I think though, when you're dealing with number one, I predict Donald Trump is going to win this one. And the fight is going to be per second. Now Ted Cruz still has a ground game second to none. He's able to target those who are inclined already to support him. And by the way though, this could all be changed if Cruz and Trump don't stop fighting.

If they divide their own vote that is what will give Rubio a chance to move into second. So, if Cruz and Trump stop fighting, Cruz will take second. If they don't, Rubio will take second. That's exactly where Rubio wants to be leading into South Carolina.

BOLTON: OK. So, Tammy, I heard you loudly and clearly. You think that Donald Trump will win New Hampshire.

BRUCE: Yes.

BOLTON: I have to assume that's because there are so many independents...

BRUCE: Yes.

BOLTON: ... and he seems to be appealing in that way to people. Here he is when confronted at a town hall in New Hampshire.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Throughout the course of this campaign you said some disparaging comments about women, about people from other countries, other religions, and about everybody who has disagreed with you. Explain to me how I can look at my daughters and have them look up to a President Trump as a role model.

TRUMP: Nobody has more respect for women that I do. I have so many women executive. I have been great to women and women have been great to me. They've done a great job. I do bring up things that are things that people don't want to bring up. When I brought up the Muslim problem, you know, it's very interesting. I brought that problem up and all of a sudden the world started going wild and now the world is agreeing with me.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BOLTON: John, what do you think of Trump's response there?

ROWLEY: Well, I'm waiting for him to take credit for inventing the internet. I mean, he's really delusional that he is the first person that's talked about so many things in this campaign when a lot of different people in another Republican Party have talked about them for a long time.

Whether it's going to impact him or not, I mean, he's appealing to a sliver of the electorate, really the most conservative Tea Party angry or whiter or anti-Obama wing of the party sliver of the national electorate.

And I don't know that it will impact him in New Hampshire. I mean, the thing about New Hampshire voters though, is they are contrarians and I'm not sure if that means they deliver a surprise for Trump. They certainly have delivered surprises before, but, you know, that there may be one of those equal and opposite reactions to some late polling that we've certainly seen in both parties in New Hampshire in all of that.

BRUCE: Can I chime in one additional element that helps Trump...

BOLTON: Sure.

BRUCE: is the heroin addiction there in New Hampshire. It's a big issue. We know that it's related to the border, to the open border, to the ability of drugs moving up into this country. That is going to be something that matters from.

And also I notice that he did change his approach. He noted that he might - - he would like to win but he is not sure. I mean, his demeanor does seem to have shifted off of that for a span of 12 hours.

(CROSSTALK)

BOLTON: So, his tone is changing?

BRUCE: Yes, a little bit.

BOLTON: OK.

BRUCE: And I think that will -- that will help him obviously.

BOLTON: BOLTON: Tammy and John, stay with me, please. Other things to ask you about. In the meantime, on the other side of the aisle, last night's democratic debate Senator Sanders and Hillary Clinton sparred hard.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

BERNIE SANDERS, (D) U.S. PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE: Secretary Clinton does represent the establishment.

HILLARY CLINTON, (D) U.S. PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE: Senator Sanders is the only person who I think would characterize me a woman running to be the first woman president as exemplifying the establishment and enough is enough.

SANDERS: And one of the things we should do is not only talk the talk but walk the walk. I am very proud to be the only candidate up here who does not have a super PAC, who's not using huge sums of money from Wall Street.

(APPLAUSE)

CLINTON: You will not find that I ever changed the view or a vote because of any donation that I ever received. So, I think it's time to end the very artful smear that you and your campaign have been carrying out in recent weeks. And let's talk -- let's about the issues.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BOLTON: My political power panel will be back with me shortly to tell you what they think of those two sides.

All right. Fox Business is going to be bringing you live coverage of our nation's first primary. It happens Tuesday, February 9the. Neil Cavuto, he's going to be bringing you those results from New Hampshire as soon as they come in starting at 7.55 Eastern Time.

If you look at the markets today, stocks got crushed. Fewer than forecast jobs were added to the U.S. economy. In his State of the Union address, President Obama had this to say to critics.

Because there's no way you can have a disconnect between public market comes which have clearly falling down a lot this year and what was paid for unicorns in the current market.

BOLTON: You have invested in some -- well, numerous hot stocks. Some of which are still private, some of which are still public, which public one are the most proud of? That you saw early, you got in early.

CLAVIER: I'm still happy what Fitbit has done. Obviously, down 50 percent this year, but I think that it's actually the company which makes the world a better place because it helps people to get in shape.

And I think that hopefully the market we understand that, you know, the Apple watch won't kill it, that all of its competitors won't kill them (Inaudible) and the new line up of products that are actually pretty exciting. The market doesn't like it. But, you know, still has 17 awards.

BOLTON: There's a new design, it looks good.

CLAVIER: Fashion focused.

BOLTON: With a company, though, such as Yahoo clearly on the ropes. Do you get anxious that there are fewer potential buyers for any other companies that you might be investing?

CLAVIER: So, you know, it's actually pretty unusual to see those valuations that are coming down which actually are going to get the buyers back to the table of negotiating with hot company's potential buyouts.

Because over the last couple of years the expectations were so high that the remaining (ph) market was pretty tipped. With, you know, all those valuations sort of coming down. I've heard numerous sort of called, there are people saying, OK, well, none of the market is back on track, let's have a discussion.

BOLTON: All right. That's the good start of all things. Jeff Clavier, thank you so much. Joining me there, partner at SoftTech VC.

Super Bowl Sunday is this weekend. You know that. Cheryl Casone is there. An update from her in just a minute.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BOLTON: It's Super Bowl weekend. Broncos quarterback, Peyton Manning trying snag one more championship as retirement looms. The rising Carolina Panthers star, Cam Newton trying to lead his team to the first Super Bowl title.

Cheryl Casone is there in San Francisco. What's the atmosphere like, Cheryl?

CASONE: Well, this is the NFL experience. It's a fan's dream. If you love football, in fact, we're right in front of radio row, we've been here a lot of the afternoon. And this is where a lot of the big players.

I mean, you should have seen Tony Romo, quarterback for the Cowboys. You couldn't even move in this space. So, it's a lot of fans, a lot of media, a lot of companies. Everybody trying to kind of get a piece of the football pie, if you will.

All the buzz, I got to say, is about Peyton Manning. So many questions about whether or not he's going to retire after the season and still no answers from him. He's going to have sell everybody himself.

Roger Goodell was here, of course, a lot of the executives. Also, about a million people coming into the San Francisco Bay area. Security has been insane. Blackhawk helicopters actually flying above the skies at San Francisco.

The FBI, Department of Homeland Security surveilling everything. There's camera everywhere. And I got to tell you, anybody that is going to be at the Levi Stadium on Sunday, for the big game, Deirdre, smile for the surveillance camera because they've got so many cameras on that stadium. They are concerned about security.

They wanted to make sure that Super Bowl 50 goes off without a hitch. I got to tell you, the other big piece of buzz right now and you're going to love this, Coldplay, Beyonc,, Bruno Mars, right? There is a mystery guest cannot get it out of the half time, people. We've all been trying today, but with all those reporters and we don't know.

BOLTON: Well, enjoy it all. Cheryl Casone joining us there from the Super Bowl site. Speaking of super stars, Making Money with Charles Payne starts now.

END
